Increase z-index to coincide with slide well adding z-index

https://github.com/tantaman/Strut/pull/220 shows a need to add a z-index to the slide well, but this means the navbar-inner z-index needs to be increased so the dropdown isn't covered up.

Two UI niceties for the slide well

*Adds padding to the bottom* so the "Add Slide" button is easily accessible on mouseover when the slide being appended to is at the very bottom of the list (removes the need to scroll further to access it & generally makes it easier/nicer to use).

*Adds a z-index* so slide content doesn't obstruct the slide well. Went with the same z-index that's already being used for the navbar (figured the navbar & slide well are equally important).

Ui-selectable class is no longer removed from the transition editor

Need to go over and possibly re-factor all the background and surface
choosing code.  It started simple but got steadily more complicated and
convoluted as more capabilities were added such as:

1. Deck background
2. Per slide background
3. Deck surface
4. Per slide surface
5. Reset slide to deck background
6. Reset slide to deck surface
7. Custom bg image (per slide or deck)
8. Custom surface image (per slide or deck)
9. Handle old decks that are missing the surface attribute
10. Handle old decks that are missing the deck attribute
11. Preview the surface as user hovers their mouse over it
12. Preview the background
13. Apply the surface as the slide background for slides that are not
displayed on a surface
14. Apply a transparent background for the slide background for slides
that should be transparent

...
Inner bg background positioning

Added capabilities to generators and saved the currently active
generator

Each generator has a set of "capabilities."  The capabilities will be
used to correctly construct the overview mode.

For each capability, a new item is added to the overview mode.

E.g.: freeFormStepping will bring up the impress like editor
2dStepping will bring up the reveal like editor
cannedTransitions will bring up the list of canned transitions that can
be applied.

Having all capabilities will bring up all editors (although free form
stepping and 2d stepping would naturally conflict with one another)
Closes the generator menu after making a selection

Document.write leaks a new window every time it is used.

Launching a presentation caused us to leak 2 megs of memory with the
document.write solution.  Launching n presentations would leak n*(2+)
megs.

Update to use innerHtml but in a much more
streamlined way that actually ended up being simpler than document.write.

Save off of css based shapes before scraping and moving to SVG shapes

The problem that I ran into was coloring the CSS based shapes.

Applying an inline style such ass "border-color: red" cause all border
colors (even those that should be transparent) to be overridden.

After resolving that problem there was an issue with applying colors to
:before and :after pseudo elements since you can't apply inline styles
to pseudo elems.

After figuring out how to resolve that (by generating classes and
inserting them at the head of the document) I decided it would
be too much headache to try to manage those classes since
they would be user-generated based on the color selection tool.  I'd
have to manage saving them, not leaking them, rendering them to the
various presentations backends and so on.

The final decision is to use SVG shapes an apply inline styles to the SVG.

Uploads local images to imgur in order to keep presentations small

This stems from how presentations are sync'ed to RemoteStorage.
We don't want to stick images in as base64 and keep sync'ing those
files across the network.  We're using imgur to host the images
until we can save them directly to the user's remoteStorage.

LocalStorage presents other problems that we need to figure out
how to remedy.

jquery UI was removed as a dependency so "sortable" had to be
re-implemented.

Turns out that that isn't so straightforward once you get issues
such as scrolling, first & last elements, 2-dimensional sorting
and what not involved.

The current implementation of "sortable" requires the
scrollParent (if one exists) to be passed in
so it can determine the viewport offsets.

Updated todo to sketch out the future import package plan

This plan allows us to run requirejs apps without building them!
Exported packages get written into requirejs.config({paths:...});

This allows a consumer to do:
require(['package/name/class'], function(Klass) {
});

and package/name gets re-written to the actual path as defined
in the requirejs.config.

The paths are determined by using a config.js that lists
the bundles we want and the location of an rmap file.

The rmap is loaded and the rmap contains a mapping
from bundle name to bundle location / path.

Needed bundles are loaded and their manifest.js is read.
The exported packages in manifest.js are read and used to configure
requirejs.config({paths:})

basically we stick the package names as keys in paths and
bundle-location + package name as the values.

i.e., we can import package/name/class
and that gets re-written to
bundle-location/package/name/class
because of the pathing rules in requirejs.

Packages must be separated by '/' and not '.' due to how
requirejs handles path mapping.

Function.prototype.bind.call.apply(Function.prototype.bind, [undefined])
